text:
I would like us
to consider that,

about how we bring our
authentic self into situations.
Because I find that I--
and a lot of people--
hide those broken pieces.

We like to pretend as
if those don't exist.

We like to wear the
mask, which then,

as I said in the beginning, is
created by somebody somewhere.

Somebody said, oh, this is the
perfect way to be a leader,

or this is the perfect
way to be a mom,

or this is the perfect way to
be a child or sibling or friend
or professor.

Professor Bad Ass in the
building, by the way.
But it's not true.

Those things-- the ways
that we are are important.

And bringing your
authentic self--

it's like this phrase and this
saying that I feel like we all
carry and we hope we do it.

We're all hoping that
we're doing that thing.
But are you wearing the mask?
Are you wearing the mask?
I'm talking about today.

I'm not talking about
some far off time

in the future when you're doing
something completely amazing.
I'm talking about today.

And the crazy thing
about the mask

is that once you put it down,
it's easy to pick it back up.
Oh, it is easy.

Oh, and by the way, maybe
it's not even the old mask.
It's a new mask.

You got rid of that mask and
went and picked up that one.

Because somebody told
you that this is the way
you're supposed to be.
Again, lies.
Those are not facts.

So let's talk about
that a little bit.
I'm going to share--

I'm going to be super
vulnerable in this space.

Here's all the vulnerability
right here at your feet.
I am a broken person.

There's all kind of
pieces floating around.
And it has taken time--

and by the way, still
present, active word--

to put the pieces back together
in this Kintsugi type of way,

to fashion a new
being, new identity,

new attitude, new spirit
out of the understanding

that putting those
pieces back together

is actually a more
beautiful experience.

So we're in a global
pandemic obviously.
It is why we are not together.
And at the beginning--
I don't know.

Maybe some people
still say it now.

But at the beginning, I
remember a lot of people

saying, well, when
things go back to normal,

when everything is
back the way it was,
we'll do x, y, and z thing.
Well, you know what?

It is never going
back to normal.
We know that.
There's no normal.
This thing does not exist.
There is no normal.

And if we stopped
thinking about that,

if we stopped waiting
for that moment,

perhaps we would
actually use this moment

to do the most
amazing things ever.

Perhaps we would use this
very moment in time to create.

And I'm not at all making
light of what is happening.

I'm not at all making light
of the horror that is going on

in people's lives, whether
that is yourself being ill

or somebody else being ill
or somebody passing away

or the loss of
opportunities or jobs

or the stress of being in close
quarters with maybe people you
don't like.
Let's talk about it.

That perhaps if we stopped
thinking about when things

go back to normal, we
would do x, y, and z thing,

we would actually put
together the pieces of what

we have today and
create something new,

something brand new,
something amazing.

There are also parts of
myself that have nothing

to do with the global pandemic,
that have built up over time.

I think about experiences in
my life that make me who I am,

that make me unique, and
accepting those and using

those as ways to really show
up and make a difference.

And again, it sounds
so corny sometimes

when you say it like that,
but it's really true.

Understanding that your own
unique set of experiences

are actually what make you
incredible in these spaces
that we're in--
gosh.

If more of us understood that,
how amazing would our world be?
Seriously, every day.

Again, not just in some
distant way into the future.

It's just now, that if we think
about all of the experiences.

So for me, again, and super
transparency, something

I talk about all the time,
but I'll tell you now,

which is that my
experiences are built
over a lot of different things.

When I was five, my
family had to leave

Ghana, which is where my
parents were originally from,
because there was a coup.

By the way, I was
super triggered

by the events at the
Capitol last week

because it was so reminiscent
of that time in Ghana.

But there was a coup, a military
takeover of the government.
And my father was in Parliament.
He was a member of Parliament.

And so his government
was overthrown.

He was thrown into
political detention, which
is pretty much like prison.

And my mother had to escape
Ghana in the dead of night

with me, my two younger
sisters, and she

was pregnant with
my youngest sister.

I still don't know how
in the hell she did that.
It's actually incredible.

But the trauma of that time was
something that I didn't really
think about.
I didn't put it all into--

I didn't think about
it, how it built me.

At five, to think about
that kind of shake up,

that moment where your world
is just thrown off its axis.

And now, all of a sudden, being
coveted and loved and adored
was stripped away.
Everything gone overnight.

And we came to the US
under political asylum
to Washington, DC actually.

And in that time, the difference
in how we were treated
was so stark.

Having gone from, like I said,
being adored to then somehow
being less than.

I remember being in
the grocery store
around that time with my mom.

And like I said, she
had a lot going on.

And she had my youngest sister
in the front of the cart and me

and my other sister were
sort of toddling around her

and she was pregnant and she was
trying to reach for something.

And she inadvertently knocked
over a bunch of boxes.

And I remember one of the
store clerks was sort of nearby
and he screamed at her.
It was just like, [GRUNT].

I don't remember the exact
words, but I remember the anger

and feeling afraid and just
being like, oh, my gosh.

And that experience-- the only
reason I share it with you is

that many years later,
I was working at Uber--
shout out to Frances--

and we were working
on a program thinking
about how to essentially--

this is going to
sound so strange,

but essentially to
make the drivers human.

because think about
your own experiences
as you get into Ubers.

Oftentimes, you get
in, you're busy,
you're doing your own thing.

Maybe you're not
interacting with the driver.
I'm not saying that you have to.

It's just that I think
sometimes in those situations,
they sort of disappear.
They're non-entities.
We don't consider them.

And we were talking
about how to do it.

And there were a lot of great
ideas being thrown around
with my team.

And because I was running
brand at the time,

and obviously brand
is about perception.

And so the challenge was to
try and figure out, well,

how are we going to make
the drivers human so
that people feel connection?

And with that connection
comes loyalty.

And therefore, you're
going to choose this ride

over choosing Lyft or choosing
some other option every time

because you're going
to see the connection,

this unique, awesome
connection with these people

who were in the
driver's seat, who have
such interesting backgrounds.

And we were sitting and talking
about that and I'm telling you,

again, it was like a bolt
of lightning struck me.

And all of a sudden, it
was like I was transported

to when I was five and thinking
about what my experience was

at that time and what
happened to my mom, what

happened to my dad, the
change in their life

which forced them to escape and
try to find a better future.

And I'm not saying that all
drivers are immigrants who
are running from some place.

But I think about
that all the time,

which is that, what
are their stories?

Seeing these folks
as non-entities

and not understanding the depth
of where they are in life.

What is it that
they could teach us?

If you had 20 minutes--
which is the average ride--

in a car with somebody,
would they be interesting?

Maybe we could create profiles
about the drivers inside

of the app so that,
as you're getting in,

you know who it is that
you're getting in with.
They're not axe murderers.
You know what I'm saying?

People, regular people who
are students, like us, trying

to do something, maybe make an
extra buck, to pay for school.

They are parents who are trying
to just put food on the table.

They are-- hell,
sometimes executives

who are trying to
save some money
to build their side hustle.

Maybe they're just people
who are interested in just
driving around the city.
I don't know.

Everybody has
something interesting.

And as that bolt of lightning
hit me, all of a sudden,

I was like, yes, actually,
that's the way to connect.
That's the way to connect.
It's like everybody has a story.

I wish that clerk at the store
had seen my mom, had seen her,

that she wasn't just this young
Black woman with too many kids

making a mess in
a store, that she

was the wife of a prominent
politician, a brilliant fashion

designer, who just happened to
be in the worst situation ever

and that she was just
trying to make it,

trying to get that goddamn
Rice Krispies off the shelf.

And that if that person
had seen her story,

perhaps there'd be a
different connection.

And so very long story
short, I contacted

one of the most brilliant
storytellers I know, Mr. Spike

Lee who happened to be my
boss early on in my career,

and I begged and pleaded
because he was like,
I'm not doing any work for Uber.
And I was like, come on, Spike.
Don't give me a hard time, man.
Come on.

And I was like, would
you please help me tell
the story of a few drivers?
We need to make it beautiful.

We need to get deeper,
behind just their name

and this anonymity
that they have.

I need to tell their
stories, give them context.
And he agreed.

He made five beautiful films
about 20 minutes in length--
average ride of a ride.

And I left before I could
see it all the way to bright,

but when it premiered, I
was so proud of the work.

And the reason I
tell you this story

is that that broken part, that
experience as a five-year-old,

came to bear so many years
later, because I allowed it to.

I could have been
embarrassed by that.

Because who wants to be
the discarded immigrant?
Nobody likes that title.
But it's important.

And it is why I'm
able to look at people

and see more than
whatever they present,

that I'm always interested
in human stories,

I'm always interested in what
made that person do this thing

or why they are here
in this very moment,
how they come to be.

There's so much
more behind people.

And so taking that as one
of the pieces of myself

that has been put
back together is

really critical in being able to
utilize it to do the good work.
I don't hide that part.
It's here.
This is part of who I am.
It makes me so unique, right?

And I know there
are parts of you

in that very same way, stories
that I'm sure you have about
experiences you've had.

Now, it doesn't have to be as
dramatic as a military coup.

But there are
experiences that you

have that are going to come
to bear, that are going

to influence the way that
you do your work, the way

that you interact with people,
that we should not hide,
that we can put back together.

There are so many others like
that, so many other pieces, so

many other stories
like that in my life

And I ask that the
exercise you take

is thinking about the pieces
of yourself that perhaps seem

so broken that you can
utilize to make something

more beautiful, to make other
experiences more beautiful.

It is very hard to
do that sometimes

because we think about
it, and it feels like,

but those things
aren't important.
I'll tell you something.

I know-- I know for sure I am
a much more powerful executive

because I am a
sort of immigrant.

I was born in the US, but I
have immigrant experiences.

I am a much better executive
because I'm a single mom
to an 11-year-old girl.

I'm a much better executive
because I'm a widow.

I'm a much better
executive because I can
twerk like nobody's business.

OK, listen, let me-- you want
me to get up and show you?
Because I could do it.
Look.
[SINGING] Body-ody-ody.
No, I'm kidding.
I'm not going to do that.
But I am.

I'm a much better executive
because of all of those things.

And therefore, I
don't hide them.
I bring them, full display.
You want to know?
Here you go.

I use them to influence
everything that I do.
And here is the center of it.
It is important.

Our individual
experiences are important.
They matter.
They count.

It's like I have been
in way too many meetings

where we talk about getting to
sort of the mass understanding.

It's like you almost got to
make everything vanilla in order
to make it connect to people.

By the way, my favorite ice
cream flavor is vanilla.

I know that's probably
shocking, but it is.

But think about how
terrible that is--

not about the
vanilla flavor, I'm

talking about making
everything vanilla.

The fact that we think that our
individual experiences can't

connect to audiences or can't
connect to our colleagues
or can't connect to others.
And that's why we hide them.
It's simply not true.
